questions.text: The sensory nerve supply of the middle ear comes from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sensory supply of the middle ear is by the tympanic branch of the Glossopharyngeal nerve. Specifically, the tympanic nerve (also known as Jacobson's nerve) enters the middle ear and forms the tympanic plexus. This plexus gives off sensory fibres that innervate the internal surface of the tympanic membrane (eardrum), the mucous membrane of the middle ear cavity, and the Eustachian tube.

Explanation of other options:

Facial nerve(Option A): The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) does not provide sensory innervation to the middle ear. It carries motor fibres to the muscles of facial expression and parasympathetic fibres to various glands, but it does not supply sensory fibres to the middle ear.

Vestibulocochlear nerve(Option C): The vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII) is responsible for hearing and balance. It does not provide sensory innervation to the middle ear.

Auriculotemporal nerve(Option D): The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) and provides sensory innervation to the anterior auricle, external acoustic meatus, and the external surface of the tympanic membrane. However, it does not supply the internal surface of the tympanic membrane or the middle ear cavity.

questions.text: Stapedius is supplied by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The posterior wall of the Middle Ear has a projection called the Pyramid.
  • From the pyramid, the Stapedius muscle tendon comes, which attaches to the stapes.
  • The stapedius muscle is supplied by the Facial nerve.

Stapedius muscle:

  • The stapedius muscle is supplied by the Facial nerve. A special nerve known as the nerve to stapedius, a branch of the facial nerve.
  • The stapedius is the smallest skeletal muscle in the human body, measuring approximately 6 millimetres in length.
  • It is located in the tympanic cavity of the middle ear, originating from the pyramidal eminence of the temporal bone and inserting onto the neck of the stapes bone.
  • Its primary function is to dampen the vibrations of the stapes, thereby reducing the amplitude of sound waves transmitted to the inner ear and protecting the cochlea from potential damage due to loud noises.
  • This branch arises within the facial canal of the temporal bone and passes through a small canal in the pyramidal eminence to reach the stapedius muscle.
  • Damage to the facial nerve or its branch to the stapedius can result in hyperacusis, a condition characterised by an increased sensitivity to normal environmental sounds.

Explanation of other options:

Cranial nerve V (Trigeminal nerve)(Option B): This nerve does not innervate the stapedius muscle. It is responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing.

Cranial nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal nerve)(Option C): This nerve provides sensory innervation to the middle ear but does not innervate the stapedius muscle.

Cranial nerve X (Vagus nerve)(Option D): This nerve does not innervate the stapedius muscle. It is involved in functions such as heart rate, digestion, and voice production.

Key takeaways:

Stapedial reflex:

  • The stapedial reflex is a protective reflex for the inner ear.
  • Its afferent is the 8th nerve, and the efferent is the 7th nerve.
  • It is absent in deafness, facial nerve lesions and Otosclerosis.

questions.text: Which ossicle has the least blood supply?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The incus has no muscle attached to it. Hence, it has the least blood supply. Therefore, it is more vulnerable to being eroded in CSOM. The Lenticular process, followed by the Long process of the Incus, is most commonly involved.

Blood supply of the middle ear:

  • The blood supply of the middle ear is derived from branches of both the external carotid artery and the internal carotid artery.
  • This supply is important for maintaining the health of the tympanic membrane, ossicles, and mucosa of the middle ear cavity.

Branches from the External Carotid Artery:

  • Deep auricular artery
  • Anterior tympanic artery
  • Stylomastoid artery
  • Posterior auricular artery

Branches from the Internal Carotid Artery:

  • Caroticotympanic artery
  • Inferior tympanic artery

questions.text: Identify the encircled structure in the middle ear cavity:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sinus tympani is the area that is encircled in the picture above.

  • It is between the ponticulus and the subiculum. These two spicules are visible in the picture.
  • It is an area of residual cholesteatoma after mastoid surgery.

Explanation of other options:

Pyramidal fossa(Option B): The pyramidal fossa is a small, hollow conical projection located on the posterior wall of the middle ear cavity. It houses the origin of the stapedius muscle, which is responsible for dampening the vibrations of the stapes bone to protect the inner ear from loud sounds. The tendon of the stapedius muscle exits the pyramidal fossa through a small aperture to insert onto the neck of the stapes.

Fossa Incudis(Option C): This is a depression in the posterior wall of the middle ear that houses the short process of the incus and its ligament. It is located superior to the pyramidal fossa.

Facial recess(Option D): This is a space in the posterior wall of the middle ear, lateral to the pyramidal eminence. It is bounded medially by the facial nerve and laterally by the tympanic annulus. The facial recess is important surgically for accessing the middle ear and mastoid without disturbing the posterior canal wall.

questions.text: is the name of a structure marked with "P" in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure marked P is the promontory of the middle ear.

  • Bulge on the medial wall
  • Due to basal turn of the cochlea
  • The tympanic plexus lies on the promontory.

In the above picture:

  • m-Malleus
  • i-Incus
  • s-Stapes
  • rw-Round Window
  • pyr-Pyramid
  • tt-Tensor tympani
  • ch-Chorda Tympani nerve

Explanation of other options:

Ponticulus(Option A): It extends from the pyramidal eminence to the promontory on the medial wall of the tympanic cavity. The ponticulus serves as the superior boundary of the sinus tympani, a recess located posterior to the promontory. This anatomical feature is significant in middle ear surgery, particularly in procedures involving the sinus tympani and facial recess.

Pyramid(Option C): Also known as the pyramidal eminence, this is a conical projection on the posterior wall of the tympanic cavity. It houses the origin of the stapedius muscle.

Processus cochleariformis(Option D: This is a hook-like projection on the anterior wall of the tympanic cavity, anterior to the oval window. It serves as a pulley for the tendon of the tensor tympani muscle

questions.text: Identify the bone shown in the image
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image is the middle ear ossicle, Incus. Referred to as the anvil, the incus is the middle ossicle. It connects the malleus to the stapes and transmits sound vibrations between them.

Middle ear ossicles:

  1. Malleus
  2. Incus
  3. Stapes

Size: Malleus>Incus>Stapes. The stapes is the smallest bone in the body.

The hyoid bone is located in the neck and is not part of the middle ear. It supports the tongue and serves as an attachment point for muscles associated with swallowing and speech. Hence, Option D is ruled out.

choices.text: Tensor tympani tendon arises from the anterior wall of the middle ear
The Jugular bulb lies about the floor of the middle ear
The Endolymphatic sac lies in the epidural space and reabsorbs endolymph
Epitympanum is the narrowest part of the middle ear

questions.text: All of the following are true about the anatomy of the ear except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The middle ear has three parts- epitympanum, mesotympanum and hypotympanum.
  • Mesotympanum is the narrowest part - Epitympanum (Attic) is the deepest part of the middle ear.
  • Hence, the above Option D is wrong.

Explanation of other options:

Option A: True, the tendon of the tensor tympani muscle originates from a canal in the anterior wall of the middle ear and inserts onto the handle of the malleus.

Option B: True, the jugular bulb is located in the floor (jugular wall) of the middle ear, separating the tympanic cavity from the jugular fossa.

Option C: True, the endolymphatic sac is located on the posterior surface of the petrous portion of the temporal bone, in contact with the dura mater. It is involved in the regulation of endolymph volume and pressure within the inner ear.

choices.text: Tympanic segment of the facial nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the Facial recess?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The tympanic segment of the facial nerve is not a boundary for the facial recess, and hence Option B is correct.
  • The facial recess is the Surgical landmark for posterior tympanotomy. It is a triangular space in the middle ear, crucial for surgical access to the middle ear and the cochlea.

Boundaries of the Facial recess are:

  • Medial boundary - Vertical segment of facial nerve (Mastoid segment), Option C ruled out.
  • Lateral boundary - Chorda tympani, Option D ruled out.
  • Superior boundary - Fossa incudis (short process of incus), Option A ruled out.

choices.text: Fibres of the lateral malleolar fold

questions.text: Prussak's space is bounded by all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The short process of the Incus does not form the boundary of Prussak's space.

Boundaries of Prussak's space:

  • Superior - Fibres of the lateral malleolar fold, Option A ruled out.
  • Inferior - Lateral process of the Malleus, Option C ruled out.
  • Lateral - Shrapnell's membrane, Option B ruled out.
  • Medial - Neck of malleus

Trautmann's triangle - This is a triangular space bounded by:

  • Bony labyrinth anteriorly
  • Sigmoid sinus posteriorly
  • Dura containing the superior petrosal sinus superiorly.

The boundaries of Macewen's triangle are as follows:

  • Superiorly: Suprameatal crest
  • Anterior-inferiorly: Posterosuperior wall of external auditory canal
  • Posteriorly: A tangential line to the posterior canal wall

choices.text: Ponticulus is the bony spicule between the oval and round windows
Subiculum is the bony spicule from the promontory to the pyramid
Donaldson's line is a surgical landmark for the Posterior cranial fossa
The Facial recess is the surgical landmark for posterior tympanostomy

questions.text: Which of the following is an appropriate statement?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The facial recess is the surgical landmark for posterior tympanostomy
  • Subiculum(Option B) separates the oval and round windows.
  • Ponticulus(Option A) runs from the promontory to the pyramid
  • Donaldson's line(Option C) is a surgical landmark for the endolymphatic sac
  • Trautmann's triangle is a surgical landmark for the posterior cranial fossa
  • McEvan's triangle (suprameatal triangle) is a surgical landmark for the mastoid antrum.

choices.text: Korner's septum is a remnant of the petrosquamous suture
Subiculum is a bony spicule that separates the oval and the round windows
Processus Cochleariformis indicates the basal turn of the cochlea.
The Canal for the Tensor tympani lies on the anterior wall of the middle ear.

questions.text: Which is not a true match about the anatomical aspects of the ear
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Processus cochleariformis is a hook-like process on the medial wall of the middle ear that marks the first genu of the facial nerve. The tendon of the tensor tympani takes a turn here to attach to the malleus. It does not indicate the basal turn of the cochlea. Hence, it is the wrong answer.
  • Promontory indicates the basal turn of the cochlea and not the processus cochleariformis.
  • Korner's septum (also called the petrosquamosal lamina) is a bony plate that is indeed a remnant of the petrosquamous suture. Option A ruled out.
  • The subiculum is a thin bony ridge below the round window niche that separates it from the oval window above. Option B ruled out.
  • The Canal for the Tensor Tympani runs along the anterior wall and carries the tensor tympani muscle, which passes around the processus cochleariformis. Option D ruled out.

questions.text: Which of these is not found on the medial wall of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pyramid lies on the posterior wall. The tendon of the Stapedius muscle arises from it.

The medial wall of the middle ear has -

  • Promontory - a bulge on the medial wall due to the basal coil of the cochlea. Option A ruled out.
  • Tympanic plexus (IXth N) - lies on the promontory.
  • Oval window - into which the footplate of the stapes is fixed. Option D ruled out.
  • Round window - covered by secondary tympanic membrane, Option C ruled out.
  • Processus cochleariformis - a hook-like process which marks the first genu of the facial nerve
  • Ponticulus, Subiculum and Sinus tympani in between these two bony spicules
  • Horizontal segment of the Facial nerve canal

The anterior wall of the middle ear:

  • The anterior wall has a thin plate of bone, which separates the cavity from the internal carotid artery.
  • It also has two openings: the lower one for the eustachian tube and the upper one for the canal of the tensor tympani muscle.

The lateral wall of the middle ear:

  • The lateral wall is formed largely by the tympanic membrane and, to a lesser extent, by the bony outer attic wall called the scutum.
  • The tympanic membrane is issemi-transparentt and forms a "window" into the middle ear.
  • It is possible to see some structures of the middle ear through the normal tympanic membrane, e.g. the long process of incus, incudostapedial joint and the round window.

The posterior wall of the middle ear:

  • The posterior wall lies close to the mastoid air cells. It presents a bony projection called the pyramid through the summit of which appears the tendon of the stapedius muscle to attach to the neck of the stapes.
  • Aditus, an opening through which the attic communicates with the antrum, lies above the pyramid. The facial nerve runs in the posterior wall just behind the pyramid.
  • The facial recess or the posterior sinus is a depression in the posterior wall lateral to the pyramid. It is bounded medially by the vertical part of the VIIth nerve, laterally by the chorda tympani and above by the fossa incudis.
  • Surgically, the facial recess is important, as direct access can be made through this into the middle ear without disturbing the posterior canal wall (intact canal wall technique).

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral wall of the mastoid antrum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • It is a large, air-containing space in the upper part of the mastoid and communicates with the attic through the aditus. Its roof is formed by tegmen antri, a continuation of the tegmen tympani and separates it from the middle cranial fossa.
  • The lateral wall of the antrum is formed by a plate of bone, which is on average 1.5 cm thick in the adult. It is marked externally on the surface of the mastoid by suprameatal (MacEwen's) triangle.
  • The below image shows the Suprameatal triangle, medial to it lies the mastoid antrum.

Explanation of other options:

Mastoid process(Option A): While anatomically adjacent to the mastoid antrum, it does not directly form the lateral wall of the antrum.

Petrous temporal bone(Option C): This constitutes the medial wall of the antrum, not the lateral aspect.

Tympanic cleft(Option D): This refers to the middle ear space, not a structural wall of the mastoid antrum.

questions.text: Identify the middle ear landmark marked with a blue-yellow arrow.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The one that is marked by the blue arrow is the round window.

The round window (fenestra cochleae) is a key structure that:

  • Marks the posterior extremity of the cochlea's basal turn-it's located at the lower back part of the cochlear spiral.
  • It is covered by a flexible round window membrane that vibrates out of phase with the stapes at the oval window-this allows fluid in the cochlea to move and pressure waves to form, essential for hearing.
  • Ensures proper transmission of sound and prevents pressure buildup inside the cochlea, acting almost like a pressure-release valve.

Transcanal endoscopic view of the retro tympanum and pyramidal eminence with a 0° endoscope. The ponticulus is a ridge of bone arising from the pyramidal eminence to the promontory region, dividing the sinus tympani from the posterior sinus

  • Pr - promontory, Option D ruled out.
  • s - stapes
  • su - subiculum
  • p - ponticulus
  • st - sinus tympani
  • ps - posterior sinus
  • pe - pyramidal eminence, Option C ruled out.
  • FN - facial nerve
  • RW - round window
  • in - incus
  • ma - malleus
  • cp - cochleariform process

choices.text: Conduction of sound energy to the inner ear

questions.text: The main function of the middle ear is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The middle ear converts sound of greater amplitude but lesser force to that of lesser amplitude but greater force.
  • This function of the middle ear is called the impedance matching mechanism or the transformer action.
  • This is to counterbalance the loss of sound energy in the inner ear fluids.

This function of the middle ear is called the impedance matching mechanism or the transformer action. It is accomplished by:

  • Lever action of the ossicles. The handle of the malleus is 1.3 times longer than the long process of the incus, providing a mechanical advantage of 1.3.
  • The hydraulic action of the tympanic membrane. The area of the tympanic membrane is much larger than the area of the stapes footplate, the average ratio between the two being 21:1. As the effective vibratory area of the tympanic membrane is only two-thirds, the effective areal ratio is reduced to 14:1, and this is the mechanical advantage provided by the tympanic membrane. According to some workers (Wever and Lawrence), out of a total of 90 mm2 area of human tympanic membrane, only 55 mm2 is functional, and given the area of stapes footplate (3.2 mm2), the areal ratio is 17,1 and total transformer ratio (117×1.3is 22.1.
  • Curved membrane effect. Movements of the tympanic membrane are more at the periphery than at the centre, where the malleus handle is attached. This, too, provides some leverage.

Explanation of the incorrect options:

Conduction(Option A)- True, but not the main specialised function.

Amplification(Option B)- Also occurs, but it's part of impedance matching.

Pitch enhancement(Option D)- Incorrect; pitch is analysed mainly in the cochlea.

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for the opening of the Eustachian tube during swallowing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tensor veli Palatini is responsible for the opening of the Eustachian tube during swallowing.

Eustachian tube:

  • It connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx.
  • Total Length 36 mm of which Outer 12mm is bony& Inner 24mm is cartilagenous
  • Angulation at birth is nearly horizontal tube where whereas in adults it is 45° with a horizontal orientation.
  • The main function of the Eustachian tube is middle ear ventilation.
  • The tensor veli palatini muscle opens the tube during swallowing.

Explanation of other options:

Stylopharyngeus(Option A): This muscle elevates the pharynx and larynx during swallowing and is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). It does not contribute to the opening of the Eustachian tube.

Tensor tympani(Option C): located in the middle ear, this muscle dampens sounds by pulling the malleus medially. It has a minor role in opening the Eustachian tube but is primarily involved in the acoustic reflex.

Superior constrictor(Option D): Part of the pharyngeal constrictor muscles, it constricts the pharynx during swallowing but does not affect the Eustachian tube.

questions.text: What is the most accurate test to detect Eustachian tube dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tympanometry is the best test assessment of Eustachian tube function.

  • This test records compliance of the TM and Ossicle. (Freedom of movement on change of EAC air pressure)
  • Recording the movement of the Tympanic membrane and Ossicles on the changes in EAC pressure will generate curves.

Explanation of other options:

Politzer Test(Option A): Involves inflating the middle ear via the Eustachian tube using air introduced into the nostrils. While it can indicate Eustachian tube patency, it is less reliable and not commonly used in modern clinical practice.

Valsalva(Option B):

  • It is a forceful expiration with a closed nose and closed mouth.
  • Requires the patient to exhale forcefully with the mouth closed and nostrils pinched. This manoeuvre can open the Eustachian tube temporarily, but it is not a definitive test for dysfunction.

Rhinomanometry(Option C): Measures nasal airway resistance and is primarily used to assess nasal patency, not Eustachian tube function.

Key takeaways:

Eustachian tube catheterisation:

  • It is an invasive method, not used nowadays.

Eustachian tube perforation:

  • It is done with the help of a Politzer bag has an olive-shaped tip that is kept in the nostril, and the bag is in the doctor's hand, and we see whether TM moves on deflation of the bag.

Toynbee's manoeuvre:

  • It uses negative pressure to test the eustachian tube function. It is a more physiological test.
  • It is performed by asking the patient to swallow while the nose has been pinched. This draws air from the middle ear into the nasopharynx and causes inward movement of the tympanic membrane.
  • The remaining three tests use positive pressure, which causes outward movement of the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with complaints of hearing their voice loudly and notes a sensation of ear fullness. Otoscopic examination reveals a hypermobile tympanic membrane that moves with respiration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A patulous Eustachian tube (PET) is a condition where the Eustachian tube, which normally remains closed, stays abnormally open. This leads to the transmission of internal sounds, such as one's voice, breathing, and heartbeat, directly to the middle ear, resulting in a phenomenon known as autophony.

Clinical features of PET:

  • Autophony: Patients often describe hearing their voice, breathing, or heartbeat unusually loudly.
  • Hypermobile tympanic membrane: The tympanic membrane may move visibly with respiration due to the open Eustachian tube.
  • Additional symptoms: These can include a sensation of fullness in the ear, muffled hearing, tinnitus (ringing in the ear), and pressure changes in the ear during breathing.
  • Factors contributing to PET: Potential causes include significant weight loss, hormonal changes (e.g., pregnancy, use of oral contraceptives), dehydration, stress, and certain medications.

Explanation of other options:

Serous Otitis Media(Option A): Typically presents with a sensation of fullness and muffled hearing due to fluid accumulation in the middle ear. The tympanic membrane may appear retracted or bulging, but it is not hypermobile. Autophony is not a characteristic symptom.

Palatal Myoclonus(Option B): Involves involuntary rhythmic contractions of the soft palate muscles, leading to a clicking sound in the ear. It does not cause hypermobility of the tympanic membrane or autophony.

Tympanosclerosis(Option D): Characterised by calcification and scarring of the tympanic membrane, leading to reduced mobility. It does not cause hypermobility or autophony.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument used in the evaluation of Eustachian tube function.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Middle Ear Ventilation Tube (Grommet):

This is a treatment device, not a diagnostic instrument. It is surgically inserted into the eardrum to ventilate the middle ear in cases of chronic otitis media with effusion, not for evaluating Eustachian tube function. Another name for the middle ear ventilation tube is pneumatic equalising tube (P.E. tubes).

P.E. tube placement is the most common operation done on children. A large number of children have problems with fluid in the ears and recurrent ear infections. P.E. tubes work well for dealing with both of these problems.

Some of the indications for P.E. tube placement are:

  • Recurrent ear infections, greater than four or five bouts per year
  • Fluid in the middle ear that doesn't clear in a six to twelve-week period.
  • An infection that doesn't clear up with antibiotic treatment.
  • Severely retracted eardrums

Explanation of other options:

Politzer bag(Option B):

The Politzer bag is a pear-shaped rubber bulb connected to a tube, used to perform the Politzer manoeuvre. This technique involves inflating the middle ear by forcing air into the nasopharynx during swallowing, which helps assess the patency and function of the Eustachian tube.

Siegel Speculum(Option C):

This is a type of otoscopic speculum used to apply pneumatic pressure to the eardrum, aiding in the assessment of its mobility. However, it is not specifically designed to evaluate Eustachian tube function.

Pneumatic otoscope(Option A):

This device is used to examine the tympanic membrane (eardrum) for mobility by applying varying air pressures. While it assesses the eardrum's response, it does not directly evaluate the Eustachian tube function. on

choices.text: Adenoid Hypertrophy & Otitis media with effusion
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma & Otitis media with effusion

questions.text: A seven-year-old child patient has mild hearing loss along with nasal obstruction, crowding of upper teeth and a dull voice. The otoscopy examination finding is given in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glue-like fluid behind the TM and Air are trapped within the glue. A retracted tympanic membrane suggests otitis media with effusion, and with history of nasal obstructions suggests adenoid hypertrophy.

Adenoid Hypertrophy & Otitis media with effusion:

  • Glue ear is also called Serous Otitis Media(SOM).
  • Its new name is OME (Otitis media with effusion)
  • It is a collection of sterile, thick, glue-like fluid in the middle ear.
  • The basic aetiology of glue ear is ET blockage.
  • The most common age for school-age children.

Aetiology:

  • Adenoid hypertrophy in Children is mostly B/L.
  • NPC in Adult is mostly U/L.

Clinical Picture:

A school-age child complaining of:

  • Heaviness in the ear (it is not a painful disease).
  • Conductive hearing loss (CHL). (10 to 40dB)
  • Poor school performance.
  • A glue-like fluid behind the TM.
  • Air bubbles are trapped within the glue.
  • Retracted tympanic membrane.
  • Very rarely bluish tympanic membrane.
  • +/- Adenoid face

Examination:

  • Glue-like fluid behind the TM.
  • Air bubbles are trapped within the glue.
  • Retracted tympanic membrane.
  • Very rarely bluish tympanic membrane.

Treatment: Surgery

  • Myringotomy in (Anteroinferior quadrant) + Grommet insertion (also called as middle ear ventilation tube ) + Adenoidectomy.

Key takeaways:

In case of only Glue ear, Tympanoplasty tubes are used for the treatment.

choices.text: Stapes defect with fixation of the footplate and lenticular process involvement
Defective lenticular process of the incus
Defective lenticular process of incus with mobile stapes

questions.text: Which is the most common type of congenital ossicular dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common congenital ossicular anomaly is stapes fixation associated with another congenital ossicular chain anomaly.

Cremer's Classification of Congenital Anomalies of the Ossicular Chain.

choices.text: Malleus and footplate of the stapes present

questions.text: As per Austin's classification of middle ear ossicular chain defect, Type C includes:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Incus and Malleus are absent, and stapes is present in Group C ossicular chain defect.

The table below shows Austin's classification of the middle ear ossicular chain defect.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented to the ENT OPD with a history of mouth breathing for the last 3 years. Otoscopy revealed Bilateral retracted TM with air bubbles visible behind the eardrumear drum. Audiological assessment shows a Type B Tympanogram and moderate conductive hearing loss. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The management of the above case is by Adenoidectomy with Grommet insertion, and the indications for the same are given below:

  • Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnoea syndrome or speech abnormalities, i.e, (rhinolalia clausa)
  • Recurrent Chronic otitis media with effusion associated with adenoid
  • Recurrent ear discharge in benign CSOM is associated with adenoiditis/adenoid hyperplasia.
  • Dental Adenoidectomy does not correct dental abnormalities, but will prevent their recurrence after orthodontic treatment.

The grommet insertion:

  • If myringotomy and aspiration combined with medical measures have not helped and fluid recurs, a grommet is inserted to provide continued aeration of the middle ear.
  • It is left in place for weeks or months or till it is spontaneously extruded.

Explanation of the incorrect options:

Coblation Adenoidectomy(Option A) - Treats the adenoids, but does not address the middle ear fluid directly.

Myringotomy with Grommet insertion(Option B) - Doesn't address the underlying adenoidal pathology, so high risk of recurrence.

Grommet insertion alone(Option C) - Again, it doesn't address the adenoids, so not the most comprehensive or effective.
